elements.content: The mixture of CuCl2·2H2O and K3[Fe(CN)6] reacts with a series of flexible bis(pyrazole-1-yl)alkane ligands, Pz-(CH2) n -Pz (n = 1 for bpzm, n = 2 for bpze, n = 3 for bpzp, and n = 4 for bpzb), under hydrothermal conditions to produce four new copper(I) cyanide complexes: {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzm)]} n (1), {[Cu2(CN)2(bpze)]} n (2), {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzp)]} n (3), and {[Cu(CN)(bpzb)]} n (4), respectively. The X-ray analyses reveal that 1 exhibits a novel three-dimensional (3D) honeycomb-like framework, 2 shows a 2-fold interpenetration two-dimensional (2D) network, 3 exhibits a 3D structure, and 4 forms a 2D grid-like structure. An interesting odd−even phenomenon is observed in the complexes: when n is odd (n is the number of the CH2 spacer of ligands), the resulting complex exhibits a 3D framework, whereas when n is even, a 2D structure is generated. It could be explained that the numbers have a close relationship with dihedral angles among pyrazole rings of the ligands which have a great effect on the structures. Luminescent properties of the four complexes have been investigated in the solid state and 1 and 3 exhibit strong emissions, while 2 and 4 generate weak or no emission.

The X-ray analyses reveal that 1 exhibits a novel three-dimensional (3D) honeycomb-like framework, 2 shows a 2-fold interpenetration two-dimensional (2D) network, 3 exhibits a 3D structure, and 4 forms a 2D grid-like structure. An interesting odd-even phenomenon is observed in the complexes: when n is odd (n is the number of the CH2 spacer of ligands), the resulting complex exhibits a 3D framework, whereas when n is even, a 2D structure is generated. It could be explained that the numbers have a close relationship with dihedral angles among pyrazole rings of the ligands which have a great effect on the structures. Luminescent properties of the four complexes have been investigated in the solid state and 1 and 3 exhibit strong emissions, while 2 and 4 generate weak or no emission.

elements.content: Four coordination polymers of copper(I) cyanides containing a series of bis(pyrazole) alkane ligands were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The polymeric structure is switched between three-dimensional frameworks and two-dimensional networks by the dihedral angle among the pyrazol rings of the flexible ligands.

The polymeric structure is switched between three-dimensional frameworks and two-dimensional networks by the dihedral angle among the pyrazol rings of the flexible ligands.

elements.content: In recent decades, the design and synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been promoted rapidly, because they have exhibited not only dramatic architectures in topology but also potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, photoluminescence, magnetism, and so on. In this field, how to design rationally and predict polymer structures is still a great challenge since various factors could impose effects on the construction, such as ligands, metal centers, solvents, and anions. Among these factors, ligands have attracted great attention as they are the most tunable. They usually induce significant varieties on both structures and properties by tiny changes on steric structures, bulks, and lengths. As a special category, homologous ligands, such as bis(imidazol-1-yl)alkanes, bis(triazol-1-yl)alkanes, and bis(tetrazol-1-yl)alkanes, are greatly focused on recently, because of their unique characters: (i) a family of ligands could be synthesized easily, in which the longest one might contain a n-hexyl chain; (ii) N-donor azole groups have shown strong coordination ability to the first-row transition metal ions; (iii) these ligands are well soluble in common solvents. Our research team has also devoted great effort to explore the unique characters of bis-triazole ligands. However, as far as we know, the ligands only containing an even number of CH2 spacers have been researched, and it is possible to generate significant variations, if a full set of homologous ligands are employed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent decades, the design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been promoted rapidly, because they have exhibited not only dramatic architectures in topology but also potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, photoluminescence, magnetism, and so on. In this field, how to design rationally and predict polymer structures is still a great challenge since various factors could impose effects on the construction, such as ligands, metal centers, solvents, and anions. Among these factors, ligands have attracted great attention as they are the most tunable. They usually induce significant varieties on both structures and properties by tiny changes on steric structures, bulks, and lengths. As a special category, homologous ligands, such as bis(imidazol-1-yl)alkanes, bis(triazol-1-yl)alkanes, and bis(tetrazol-1-yl)alkanes, are greatly focused on recently, because of their unique characters: (i) a family of ligands could be synthesized easily, in which the longest one might contain a n-hexyl chain; (ii) N-donor azole groups have shown strong coordination ability to the first-row transition metal ions; (iii) these ligands are well soluble in common solvents. Our research team has also devoted great effort to explore the unique characters of bis-triazole ligands. However, as far as we know, the ligands only containing an even number of CH2 spacers have been researched, and it is possible to generate significant variations, if a full set of homologous ligands are employed.

elements.content: On the other hand, copper(I) cyanide complexes is a suitable subject to research the homologous ligand effect. According to previous research, copper(I) cyanide complex produced by high-temperature hydrothermal synthesis has a common molecular formula of [Cu x (CN) x L y ] (L = neutral ligand), in which Cu atoms are coordinated by only L and/or cyanide groups and the ligand effect is the dominant factor to influence polymeric structures. Excluding any other auxiliary ligands and lattice solvents prevents many side-effects and establishes the uniqueness of the effect of L and neutral polymers will not get influenced by any counterions. Furthermore, the products are usually well crystallized, which could be measured by X-ray single crystal diffraction. It is well-known that some N-donor ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,10-phenanthroline, azole, and its derivative have been successfully employed to synthesize copper(I) cyanide complexes. It prompted us to use copper(I) cyanide complexes as the subject to research the homologous ligand effect.

elements.content: Herein, a set of flexible bis(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands were introduced into the copper(I) cyanide hybrid system and four novel coordination polymers were obtained under hydrothermal conditions, formulated as {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzm)]} n (1), {[Cu2(CN)2(bpze)]} n (2), {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzp)]} n (3), and {[Cu(CN)(bpzb)]} n (4), whose structures exhibited an interesting odd−even regularity.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Bpzm, bpze, bpzp, and bpzb were synthesized according to the literature method. Syntheses of the polymers were carried out in 20-mL Teflon-lined autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer on KBr disks. The fluorescent spectra were measured on a Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol), K3[Fe(CN)6] (0.330 g, 1.0 mmol), bpzm (0.148 g, 1.0 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel reactor. It was heated at 180 °C for 3 days; the suitable crystals were obtained when cooling to room temperature. They were collected after washing with H2O (2 × 5 mL) and diethyl ether (2 × 5 mL). Yield: 0.070 g, 43% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C9H8Cu2N6: C 33.03, H 2.46, N 25.68. Found: C 32.71, H 2.62, N 25.69.

elements.content: Crystallographic data of 1−4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD (1 and 3) or Rigaku Mini (2 and 4) diffractometer with MoKα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω−φ or ω scan technique. An empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths for 1−4 are listed in Tables and . CCDC 623599 (1), 727578 (2), 623600 (3), and 727579 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

X-ray Crystallographic Study

Crystallographic data of 1-4 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD (1 and 3) or Rigaku Mini (2 and 4) diffractometer with MoKα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-φ or ω scan technique. An empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths for 1-4 are listed in Tables  and . CCDC 623599 (1), 727578 (2), 623600 (3), and 727579 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

It should be mentioned that some cyanide C and N atoms in 1, 3, and 4 are really difficult to be identified among each other, which is a common phenomenon because electrons of C and N atoms of triple bond cyanide are fully delocalized, and the atoms are not recognized easily if they are in the same coordination environment. Crystallography experts always treat them as they occupy one steric site simultaneously with both 50% occupancy. According to their suggestions, drawing and describing of these complexes are based on omitting one set of C and N atoms.

elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis has been widely used to synthesize copper(I) cyanide compounds due to the following advantages: (i) rigorous conditions of high temperature and pressure in hydrothermal autoclaves often allow subtle changes to promote the generation of crystals of copper(I) cyanide complexes which may be powder in solid originally; (ii) because of the nature of the Cu+ ion and CN− anion, the products usually contain neither solvents nor counterions; (iii) hydrothermal synthesis could yield a rich series of stable chemical products for a variety system. According to the literature reported previously, a well-established hydrothermal method is employed to synthesize 1−4 with the precursors of CuCl2 and K3[Fe(CN)6], in which the latter provides cyanide anions. Moreover, all copper in 1−4 have an oxidation state of (+1) which could be directly judged by the colorless aspect (copper(II) complexes are usually blue) and crystal analysis, although the precursor of CuCl2 is exclusively in a (+2) valence state. It indicates that the Cu2+ may be reduced by the cyanide and reflects the stabilization of the copper(I) oxidation state through π-backbonding to the cyanide and aromatic imine ligands. Like common metal cyanide complexes, 1−4 could not dissolve in water and common organic solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, DMSO, and DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of 1-4 

Hydrothermal synthesis has been widely used to synthesize copper(I) cyanide compounds due to the following advantages: (i) rigorous conditions of high temperature and pressure in hydrothermal autoclaves often allow subtle changes to promote the generation of crystals of copper(I) cyanide complexes which may be powder in solid originally; (ii) because of the nature of the Cu+ ion and CN- anion, the products usually contain neither solvents nor counterions; (iii) hydrothermal synthesis could yield a rich series of stable chemical products for a variety system. According to the literature reported previously, a well-established hydrothermal method is employed to synthesize 1-4 with the precursors of CuCl2 and K3[Fe(CN)6], in which the latter provides cyanide anions. Moreover, all copper in 1-4 have an oxidation state of (+1) which could be directly judged by the colorless aspect (copper(II) complexes are usually blue) and crystal analysis, although the precursor of CuCl2 is exclusively in a (+2) valence state. It indicates that the Cu2+ may be reduced by the cyanide and reflects the stabilization of the copper(I) oxidation state through π-backbonding to the cyanide and aromatic imine ligands. Like common metal cyanide complexes, 1-4 could not dissolve in water and common organic solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, DMSO, and DMF.

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and single-crystal analysis reveals that there is only one crystallographically independent copper atom (Figure a). Cu1 is three-coordinated in a trigonal coordination geometry by a cyanide C atom, cyanide N atom, and pyrazole N atom of bpzm ligand. The four atoms, Cu1, N2, N3, and C1, are approximately coplanar with a mean deviation of 0.0034 Å. The bond distance and angles around Cu1 are 2.0871(19) Å for Cu−Npyrazole, 1.879 (2) and 1.904 (2) Å for Cu−C/N, 103.64° for N−Cu−N, 119.12° and 137.23° for C−Cu−N, which are comparable to those reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1 

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and single-crystal analysis reveals that there is only one crystallographically independent copper atom (Figure a). Cu1 is three-coordinated in a trigonal coordination geometry by a cyanide C atom, cyanide N atom, and pyrazole N atom of bpzm ligand. The four atoms, Cu1, N2, N3, and C1, are approximately coplanar with a mean deviation of 0.0034 Å. The bond distance and angles around Cu1 are 2.0871(19) Å for Cu-Npyrazole, 1.879 (2) and 1.904 (2) Å for Cu-C/N, 103.64° for N-Cu-N, 119.12° and 137.23° for C-Cu-N, which are comparable to those reported in the literature.

elements.content: In general, complex 1 is composed of CuCN chains and bpzm ligands. As shown in Figure b, the CuCN exhibit zigzag chain structures and the angles of C−Cu−N and Cu−C−N are 137.2° and 177.7°, respectively. In the ab plane, adjacent CuCN chains are parallel to each other and arranged regularly as wave-like sheets (Figure c), while those chains along the c direction are nonparallel (the dihedral angle is about 54.9°) which are connected through bpzm bridges to form a 3D honeycomb-like motif. The network topology can be simplified by representing bpzm ligands and μ1,2-cyanide ligands as linear linkers, and the trigonal Cu atoms as 3-connected nodes. The result network belongs to the ThSi2 topology with the Schlafli symbol {103} (Figure d).

The network topology can be simplified by representing bpzm ligands and μ1,2-cyanide ligands as linear linkers, and the trigonal Cu atoms as 3-connected nodes. The result network belongs to the ThSi2 topology with the Schlafli symbol {103} (Figure d).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, in which two crystallographically independent copper atoms, Cu1 and Cu2, are found. As depicted in Figure a, each copper atom exhibits a triangle coordination geometry of N2C, in which one C and N atoms are from two cyanide ligands respectively, and the other N atom is from bpze ligand. Both Cu atoms are deviated a little from their trigonal planar with approximate point-plane distances of 0.5 and 0.25 Å, and the bond lengths are in the range of 1.915−2.080 Å for Cu−N, and 1.875−1.908 Å for Cu−C, respectively. In addition, there is a weak coordination effect between Cu1 and C6B with the distance of 2.424 Å, which is smaller than the van der Waals radii of 2.8 Å (shown with dot lines in Figure a). The weak coordination bond induces a symmetric dimer formation of [Cu2(CN)2], in which the angles of C−Cu−C and Cu−C−N are 107.3 and 168.5°, respectively, and the Cu···Cu distance is about 2.6 Å, close to the distance in the copper metal (2.56 Å). The dimer can be considered as a 6-coordination connected “point” with four cyanide and two bpze ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2 

Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, in which two crystallographically independent copper atoms, Cu1 and Cu2, are found. As depicted in Figure a, each copper atom exhibits a triangle coordination geometry of N2C, in which one C and N atoms are from two cyanide ligands respectively, and the other N atom is from bpze ligand. Both Cu atoms are deviated a little from their trigonal planar with approximate point-plane distances of 0.5 and 0.25 Å, and the bond lengths are in the range of 1.915-2.080 Å for Cu-N, and 1.875-1.908 Å for Cu-C, respectively. In addition, there is a weak coordination effect between Cu1 and C6B with the distance of 2.424 Å, which is smaller than the van der Waals radii of 2.8 Å (shown with dot lines in Figure a). The weak coordination bond induces a symmetric dimer formation of [Cu2(CN)2], in which the angles of C-Cu-C and Cu-C-N are 107.3 and 168.5°, respectively, and the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is about 2.6 Å, close to the distance in the copper metal (2.56 Å). The dimer can be considered as a 6-coordination connected "point" with four cyanide and two bpze ligands.

elements.content: As shown in Figure b, the CuCN in 2 exhibit a 1D double-stranded ribbon structure, in which copper dimers play an important role as linkers. The ribbons are parallel to each other and connected by μ2-bridges of bpze to form an interesting 2-fold interpenetration 2D pattern (Figure c), in which the basic unit could be considered as a 3-connected (63) 2D network (Figure d). Moreover, if the Cu1 dimer and Cu2 atom are considered as 6-connected and 3-connected nodes, respectively, while bpze and μ1,2-cyanide ligands are considered as linkers, the network topology can be simplified, as shown in Figure e. The simplified network is constructed by 3-connected (Cu atom) and 6-connected (Cu2(CN)2) nodes in a ratio of 2:1, which can be characterized by the short vertex symbol (43)2(46.66.83). Actually, it is the dual of the “β-W” net which is important in intermetallic structures.

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and there are two crystallographically independent copper atoms. Both Cu atoms are located in 3-coordinated environments of N2C, as shown in Figure a. The two N atoms are offered by cyanide and bpzp ligand, respectively, and the C atom is from another cyanide. Cu2, C12, N1, and N4 are approximately coplanar with the mean deviation of 0.01 Å, while Cu1 is slightly deviated from the N2C plane about 1.2 Å. The bond lengths are in the range of 2.038−2.097 Å for Cu−Npyrzole, and 1.884−2.065 Å for Cu−C/N. Notably, the interaction between Cu1 and C1A is considered as a weak coordination bond because the Cu1−C1A distance (2.214 Å) is about 0.2 Å longer than common Cu−C bonds in copper(I) cyanide complexes. Similar to those in 2, Cu1 and Cu1A also form a dimer of [Cu2(CN)2] with C−Cu−C and Cu−C−N angles of 108.6 and 109.7°, respectively. In this case, the Cu···Cu distance is about 2.5 Å, which is much shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii for copper (2.8 Å), even shorter than the distance in the copper metal (2.56 Å).

elements.content: Compared with the substructures of zigzag chains and double-stranded ribbons in complexes 1 and 2, CuCN in complex 3 exhibits a novel 2D construction. As shown in Figure b, Cu1 dimers are connected to each other through cyanide ligands along the b axis, which are linked with linear Cu-CN-Cu units along the a axis. Thus, a 2D (4,82) layer construction is generated as the resulting network. To the best of our knowledge, it is rarely observed in copper(I) cyanide complexes before. Furthermore, adjacent CuCN sheets are connected together by bpzp ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c), of which two pyzole rings are linked to one dimer unit and one copper atom in different layers. In topology, the analogical simplification strategy to 2 is employed: the dimer and Cu2 atom are simplified as 6-connected and 3-connected nodes, and bpzb and μ1,2-cyanide ligands are considered as linkers. The resulting tcl/hhc topology net (Figure d) is constructed by 3-connected (Cu atoms) and 6-connected (Cu2(CN)2 dimers) nodes in a ratio of 2:1, which can be characterized by the short vertex symbol (5.72)2(56.64.73.8.9).

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, in which only one crystallographically independent copper atom is found (Figure a). Cu1 is coordinated by two bpzb ligands with pyrazole N atoms and two cyanides with C and N atoms and the four atoms define a tetrahedron coordination environment of Cu1. In 4, Cu−Npyraozole and Cu−C/N bond lengths are in the range of 2.145−2.166 Å and 1.934−1.946 Å, respectively.

elements.content: As shown in Figure b, both bpzb and cyanide act as bidentate bridging ligands, through which Cu atoms are joined together to form a irregular quadrangle of Cu4 units. In this pattern, the Cu atoms are coplanar with the longest and shortest Cu···Cu distances of 10.356 and 8.943 Å along diagonal lines. Herein, it should be mentioned that all the bis(pyrazol)alkane ligands in 1−4 have shown a unique coordination mode of μ2-bridges, although they usually act as chelators with two pyrazole N atoms in the reported complexes. Arranged alternately in bc plane, Cu4 units are assembled into a 2D grid-like network, as shown in Figure c, in which no obvious π−π stacking effect among pyrazole ring is observed. Topologically, this 4-connected Shubnikov tetragonal plane net can be characterized by the short vertex symbol (44.62) which is shown in Figure d.

elements.content: Although they have been synthesized under the same experiment conditions (method, reactants, stoichiometry ratios) and have the common molecular formula of [Cu x (CN) x L], complexes 1−4 display different dimensional conformations. In general, the 3D complexes (1 and 3) consist of the ligands containing odd methylene, while the 2D complexes (2 and 4) are constructed from the ones containing even methylene, which indicates that some kind of odd−even relationship is present between the structures and the ligands. With the increase of the ligand length, the structure of the complexes exhibits a unique alternant behavior between 2D and 3D. However, as mentioned above, the research in this field is only focused on partial homologous ligands and few examples have been documented, thus the following discussion is just based on the existing data.
elements.clean_text:
Odd-Even Phenomenon in Complexes 1-4 

Although they have been synthesized under the same experiment conditions (method, reactants, stoichiometry ratios) and have the common molecular formula of [Cu x (CN) x L], complexes 1-4 display different dimensional conformations. In general, the 3D complexes (1 and 3) consist of the ligands containing odd methylene, while the 2D complexes (2 and 4) are constructed from the ones containing even methylene, which indicates that some kind of odd-even relationship is present between the structures and the ligands. With the increase of the ligand length, the structure of the complexes exhibits a unique alternant behavior between 2D and 3D. However, as mentioned above, the research in this field is only focused on partial homologous ligands and few examples have been documented, thus the following discussion is just based on the existing data.

elements.content: From the common formula of [Cu x (CN) x L] (x = 1 or 2) 1−4 are considered as a combination of CuCN and bis(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands. Although the organic ligands only act as μ2-bridges as mentioned above, it is the key role to influence the structure of CuCN and complexes. The basic conformation of CuCN in 1−4 could be generally considered as kinds of 1D formation: zigzag chains in 1 and 4, ribbons in 2, and linear chains (-Cu2-CN-Cu2- and -Cu-CN-Cu-) in 3. In geometry, if 1D conformation in one complex is parallel, it is impossible for Cu(I) to form 3D structures like the common mode of 1D chain → 2D sheet → 3D framework because of the limited coordination number, in which one metal center must be connected with four organic ligands and six-coordinated (Chart ). Thus, parallel CuCN (2 and 4) will induce 2D networks, and only nonparallel ones (noncoplane in 1 and crossover in 3) may result in 3D frameworks. It should be mentioned that marked difference could also be found in the structures with the same dimension owing to the concrete formation of CuCN. The more distorted 3D framework of 3 may result from a complicated 2D net of CuCN in 3 than the 1D chain in 1. The 1D ribbon and 1D chain in 2 and 4 correspond with the 2-fold interpenetration 2D and common 2D networks. On the other hand, the arrangements of CuCN chains are induced by the coordination directions of two pyrazole rings of the ligand, and an experimental regularity between CuCN formation and ligands could be drawn out by investigating the structures of the ligands: the ligands containing large dihedral angles among N-donor rings (70.7° in bpzm and 96.4° in bpzp) will induce the nonparallel CuCN formation,; otherwise (0° in bpze and bpzb) the parallel mode is generated, as shown in Table . On the basis of the analyses above, the dihedral angles might be the efficient factor to control the structures: large dihedral angles → 3D, zero dihedral angle → 2D. Interestingly, for bis(pyrazole)alkane ligands, the dihedral angles also consist of odd/even characters of CH2 spacers: odd number of spacers → large dihedral angles, even number of spacers → zero dihedral angle, which induces the external odd−even phenomenon in complexes 1−4.

FT-IR spectra have been recorded for 1−4. As well as other metal cyanide complexes, the cyanide stretch in these compounds occurs in the 2079−2162 cm−1 range. As shown in Table , the number of bands and crystallographically independent cyanide groups agree very well in 2−4. In 1, only one band is observed despite the occurrence of two crystallographically independent cyanide groups. Generally, v(CN) decreases when its metal coordination number increases. In the cases of 2 and 3, the bands at 2121 and 2079 cm−1 should be assigned to the stretching absorption of the μ3-cyanide groups, respectively. A recent analysis of IR in copper(I) cyanide complexes has shown the relationship between v(CN) and copper−cyanide bond length: a long bond length > 2 Å induces a band of <2100 cm−1 in IR spectrum. This phenomenon can also be observed in 3.

The luminescent properties of 1−4 have been investigated in the solid-state at room temperature, because of their poor solubility in common solvents. 1 and 3 exhibit obvious luminescence behavior, while 2 shows a weak emission peak, and no detectable emission is observed in 4. The emission spectra have been recorded in Figure . The emission peak appears at 473 nm with λex = 320 nm for 1, 529 nm with λex = 330 nm for 2, and 515 nm with λex = 293 nm for 3, which may be generally assigned as metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). Compared to that of copper(I) cyanide, which shows a fairly strong emission at about 392 nm, these peaks are red-shifted and the intensity decreases, indicating that the flexible ligands in these compounds trend to quench the luminescence probably. Although this analysis is not quantitative, we could conclude roughly that much stronger emissions occur in 1 and 3 than that in 2 and 4 under the similar conditions, which corresponds with their 3D or 2D architectures. It hints that the luminescent properties of four compounds are greatly influenced by their structures.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized and characterized four novel copper(I) cyanides with a series of homologous flexible ligands of Pz-(CH2) n -Pz (Pz = pyrazole, n = 1−4). The ligand effect in these coordination polymers has been investigated in detail and an experimental regularity is drawn out: ligands with large dihedral angles may result in 3D structures, while the ones with zero angles only lead to 2D networks. For bis(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands, it happens to consist of the odd/even CH2 chain spacers and results in an interesting odd−even phenomenon in the structures. The spectral properties of four compounds are also measured. Compounds 1−3 exhibit luminescence emission, and the intensity is influenced by the structures of compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized and characterized four novel copper(I) cyanides with a series of homologous flexible ligands of Pz-(CH2) n -Pz (Pz = pyrazole, n = 1-4). The ligand effect in these coordination polymers has been investigated in detail and an experimental regularity is drawn out: ligands with large dihedral angles may result in 3D structures, while the ones with zero angles only lead to 2D networks. For bis(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands, it happens to consist of the odd/even CH2 chain spacers and results in an interesting odd-even phenomenon in the structures. The spectral properties of four compounds are also measured. Compounds 1-3 exhibit luminescence emission, and the intensity is influenced by the structures of compounds.

A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol), K3[Fe(CN)6] (0.330 g, 1.0 mmol), bpzm (0.148 g, 1.0 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel reactor. It was heated at 180 °C for 3 days; the suitable crystals were obtained when cooling to room temperature. They were collected after washing with H2O (2 × 5 mL) and diethyl ether (2 × 5 mL). Yield: 0.070 g, 43% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C9H8Cu2N6: C 33.03, H 2.46, N 25.68. Found: C 32.71, H 2.62, N 25.69.

Synthesis of {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzm)]} n  (1)

A mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol), K3[Fe(CN)6] (0.330 g, 1.0 mmol), bpzm (0.148 g, 1.0 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was placed in a 20-mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel reactor. It was heated at 180 °C for 3 days; the suitable crystals were obtained when cooling to room temperature. They were collected after washing with H2O (2 × 5 mL) and diethyl ether (2 × 5 mL). Yield: 0.070 g, 43% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C9H8Cu2N6: C 33.03, H 2.46, N 25.68. Found: C 32.71, H 2.62, N 25.69.

Synthesis of {[Cu2(CN)2(bpze)]} n  (2)

The procedure was the same as that in 1 except bpzm was replaced by bpze. Yield: 0.051 g, 30% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C10H10Cu2N6: C 35.19, H 2.96, N 24.63. Found: C 35.56, H 2.78, N 24.57.

Synthesis of {[Cu2(CN)2(bpzp)]} n  (3)

The procedure was the same as that in 1 except the bpzm was replaced by bpzp. Yield: 0.041 g, 23% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C11H12Cu2N6: C 37.18, H 3.40, N 23.66. Found: C 37.03, H 3.73, N 23.92.

Synthesis of {[Cu(CN)(bpzb)]} n  (4)

The procedure was the same as that in 1 except bpzm was replaced by bpzp. Yield: 0.048 g, 17% based on copper. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C11H14CuN5: C 47.21, H 5.04, N 25.03. Found: C 47.29, H 4.82, N 24.82.
